ai-dn27:30.5_0: An ascetic, brahmin, is restrained in body, speech, and mind, and develops the seven qualities that lead to awakening, becomes extinguished in this very life.
ai-dn27:31.1_0: Any mendicant from these four castes who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—is said to be foremost by virtue of principle, not without principle.
ai-dn27:31.2_0: For Vāseṭṭha, the first is the best thing in both this life and the next.
ai-dn27:32.1_0: Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra also spoke this verse:
ai-dn27:32.3_0: who take clan as the standard.
ai-dn27:32.4_0: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct
ai-dn27:32.5_0: is first among gods and humans.’
ai-dn27:32.6_0: That verse was well sung by Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra, not poorly sung; well versed in our Subrahmā, not poorly sung.

ai-dn27:32.8_0: The aristocrat is first among people
ai-dn27:32.9_0: who take clan as the standard.

ai-dn27:32.12_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-dn27:32.13_0: Satisfied, Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-dn27:32.14_0: The fourth chapter on directly knowing this is finished.
